newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Two firms bid for Taiwan high-speed railway.
newsitem.headline: Two firms bid for Taiwan high-speed railway.

text.p: Taiwan said on Wednesday that two private companies have applied to invest in the island's multi-million-dollar high-speed railway project.

"We have received two applications before the deadline at 17.00 local time (0900 GMT). We plan to open the sealed applications on Thursday," a spokesman at the Provisional Engineering Office of High Speed Rail said by telephone.
Firms from France, Germany and Japan have all voiced interest in participating in the island's planned T$441.9 billion high-speed railway project.
The office, under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, would complete initial reviews of the applicants on February 28, the spokesman said.
Final decision would be made by November 30, 1997.

Taiwan formally invited bids from local or foreign firms in October 1996 to invest in the 345-km (220 miles) high-speed railway project, connecting northern Taipei and southern Kaohsiung. The project is scheduled for completion in 2003.
Taiwan approved a bill in 1994 to allow private firms for the first time to invest in the island's railway construction projects.
To encourage investments, the bill awards tax concessions and loans to private firms that work on railway projects.
The government plans to attract 40 percent of the T$441.9 billion funding from private interests.
